FeedItems.Title: Requiring two-factor authentication on NuGet.org
FeedItems.Summary:
NuGet.org will begin requiring two-factor authentication for accounts starting March 8th.
The post Requiring two-factor authentication on NuGet.org appeared first on The NuGet Blog.

FeedItems.Summary:

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "[ReleasePrep][2022.04.08] RI dev to main" (#9087) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Merged pull request "SQL connection creation duration tracking" (#9086) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody: Added a client-side aggregated metric for SQL connection creation duration.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "IVsPackageInstallerProjectEvents/IVsPackageInstallerEvents events not raised with PackageReference" (#6872) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. Create a VSIX that registers the `IVsPackageInstallerProjectEvents` and `IVsPackageInstallerEvents`
2. Start Visual Studio with this VSIX loaded
3. Create a new solution
4. Create a new project
5. Add a NuGet reference as packages.config => Events are raised
6. Create a new project
7. Add a NuGet reference as PackageReference => Events are not raised

Code of the extension: [VSIXProject1.zip](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/files/1955574/VSIXProject1.zip)

Question: Is there a way to be notified when a PackageReference is added/removed using the NuGet UI?

## Details about Problem

NuGet product used:
VSIX in VS 2017

VS version (if appropriate): 
15.6.7

OS version:
Windows 10 v1607 14393.2125

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Large number of allocations while processing package references" (#11733) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody: When calling `GetPackageReferenceUtility.GetInstalledVersion()` and `GetPackageReferenceUtility.GetTransitivePackagesForLibrary()` large amounts of memory are allocated to execute LINQ queries; primarily due to capture classes, delegates, and enumerators. In the case of OrchardCore, this totals to ~22MB. By unrolling these LINQ queries, we can eliminate these allocations and get a small reduction in CPU usage too.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Unnecessary Allocations in SemanticVersion.ParseSections()" (#11732) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody: SemanticVersion.ParseSections() allocates a System.Tuple to return the parsed elements to the caller. Switching to using out parameters will save about 7MB of allocated memory when opening OrchardCore.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Cleanup CS0618 - obsolete API warnings from InteractiveLoginProvider" (#7676) at NuGet/Home
Closed issue "Create A/B experiment and progression for transitive dependencies" (#10760) at NuGet/Home
Closed issue "[Bug]: Generated path property not set for custom targets" (#11725) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

MSBuild.exe

### Product Version

16.11.2.50704

### Worked before?

not sure

### Impact

It's more difficult to complete my work

### Repro Steps & Context

When building the following project with `msbuild /t:ReportVariables l10n.proj` the property `PkgNuGet_CommandLine` isn't set.

```
<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk">
  <PropertyGroup>
    <TargetFrameworks/>
    <TargetFrameworks>netstandard2.0;net461</TargetFrameworks>
  </PropertyGroup>
  <ItemGroup>
    <PackageReference Include="NuGet.CommandLine" Version="6.1.0" GeneratePathProperty="true" />
  </ItemGroup>
  <Target Name="ReportVariables" DependsOnTargets="restore">
    <Message Text="PkgNuGet_CommandLine=$(PkgNuGet_CommandLine)" />
  </Target>
</Project>
```

#### Expected result:
because of specifying `GeneratePathProperty="true"` in `PackageReference` I expect `PkgNuGet_CommandLine` to be set to a path.

#### Actual result:
`PkgNuGet_CommandLine` is empty

### Verbose Logs

[output.txt](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/files/8445481/output.txt)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Feature]: Add Package Source Mapping to packes.config/MSBuild files" (#11731) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product(s) Involved

NuGet.exe, Visual Studio Package Management UI, Visual Studio Package Manager Console, MSBuild.exe, dotnet.exe

### The Elevator Pitch

We want to prevent package source confusion for security and maintainability.

The [Package Source Mapping](https://devblogs.microsoft.com/nuget/introducing-package-source-mapping/) feature is a good start, but being limit to package ID globs in NuGet.Config is not very flexible and seems difficult to maintain.

Please add the ability to specify a package source (referencing a packageSource key from NuGet.config or a URL) to the package element in packages.config and PackageReference in msbuld projects. I'd be OK looking for transitive dependencies in the same source, but having that configurable would be nice as well.

Please add something to the Visual Studio package manager UI to allow this as well. Maybe based on the source drop-down?

### Additional Context and Details

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Feature]: Allowed export list package to CSV,Json,XML" (#11730) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product(s) Involved

NuGet.exe, Visual Studio Package Manager Console, dotnet.exe, NuGet SDK

### The Elevator Pitch

Add the ability to export the output of the list package command to a file in CSV, Json, XML format so that you can easily manipulate it.

### Additional Context and Details

I would need it to create a script that checks for new package versions.

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Fix Readme.md link for "Finding an issue to work on"" (#11727) at NuGet/Home
Opened issue "Requiring two-factor authentication on NuGet.org" (#61) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody: We announced plans to require tFA on all accounts on NuGet.org. Details in the [blog post](https://devblogs.microsoft.com/nuget/requiring-two-factor-authentication-on-nuget-org/).
